module.title: Module 1: Re-Creating the Self: Making Change Happen

pages.text: There are a number of reasons why people find themselves in the criminal justice system, but the main problem is a pattern of thinking that leads to impulsive behavior without much consideration of what might happen as a result. People on probation and parole often have trouble handling stress in the first place and having to live under the rules of supervision can add to that stress.

pages.header: Worksheet 1: The Basic's of Oji's Journey
pages.text: The figure below shows how different things in your life can lead to where you are at a given moment – right now you are on community supervision. But, how did you get here? The way you think about your world led you to act in ways that are consistent with those thoughts, and those actions landed you in trouble. It’s important to remember that this is a CYCLE. So, being on supervision (an environmental situation) may, in turn, increase the kinds of thoughts that leads to more poor choices. This cycle makes it harder for you to stay out of the criminal justice system.

pages.header: Worksheet 1: The Basic's of Oji's Journey
pages.text:
How do you get out of the cycle? YOU MUST MAKE CHANGES! To reach your goals, you must change how you think, how you act, and the places you go. You can apply this idea to any part of your life that you are not happy with and set positive goals for improving your situation. In this program, your main focus is to:

Successfully serve your time on community supervision and learn new skills to manage the problems that led you here so you do not come back.

pages.header: Worksheet 1: The Basic's of Oji's Journey
pages.text: To get the hang of THE Circle of Change, try an example. Read the story on the next page about Marcus and complete the pieces of the circle.

questions.prompt: "Marcus is a 35-year-old man. He grew up in a poor neighborhood where many of his friends did illegal things to make money and survive. Marcus often robbed people whom he thought were wealthy and could afford to lose their personal belongings. He figured if he could get access to their items, then those people didn’t deserve to have them anyway. One night, he broke into a family’s home believing the house was empty. He was wrong! The police were called, and Marcus was placed under arrest. He already has a criminal record and there was evidence of his break-in, so there is a good chance he will serve jail or prison time for his crime."

What new goals might Marcus set for himself?

What new goals might you set for yourself?

pages.header: Worksheet 1: The Basic's of Oji's Journey
pages.text: Throughout this program, you will be applying THE Circle of Change to your personal situation – that is, where you are now. You will be introduced to new skills that will help you identify and change the thoughts, actions, and environments that lead to the choices you made just before your involvement in the criminal justice system or those that keep you involved. For everyone completing this program, the different parts of THE Circle of Change will be related to criminal or antisocial tendencies; for other people, they will also be related a mental health problem. Review your assessment results to find out if mental health will be a target area for you.

pages.header: Worksheet 1: The Basic's of Oji's Journey
pages.text: So, how do you know which thoughts, habits, and environments (remember, this can also include the people you hang around) are NOT helpful for achieving your goal of staying out of the criminal justice system once your supervision period is over? One way to do this is to use a mental traffic light. Just as traffic lights in the real-world help keep people safe by enforcing the rules of the road, your mental traffic light can help you stay safe in your recovery from criminal conduct and, for some people, mental illness. With the mental traffic light, you can first become aware of your thoughts, habits, and environments and then evaluate how helpful or not helpful they are in reaching your goals. Again, this model can be applied to other aspects of your life to help you stay on track with all of your goals. But, for now, your focus is to remain violation free and stay off of community supervision once your sentence ends. Review the picture below.

pages.header: Worksheet 1: The Basic's of Oji's Journey
pages.text: Use your mental traffic light throughout this program to make sure you are keeping in line with your goal of managing the problems that led you to your involvement with the criminal justice system. Remember, change is a difficult process and you won’t always see green. However, you are responsible for avoiding yellow and red whenever possible, and for learning how to prevent the negative effects of red and yellow when you do encounter them.

questions.prompt: To practice using your mental traffic light, write down one thought, one action, and one environment that you experienced recently and determine whether each one was a green, yellow, or red light in your goal of getting out and staying out of restrictive housing.

fields.text: I was recently in this place and/or with these people:

pages.text: Sometimes it’s helpful to come up with goals if you first stop to think about the problems that led you to where you are now. Knowing how you got here can help you understand what goals are necessary to move you in a more positive direction – away from your old problems. It is easy to blame your current situation on someone or something else but think about the things you are responsible for. This is what you have control over and can change.

questions.prompt: Do you notice any themes or common problems in each place (maybe a particular thought, person, or hangout spot)?

pages.text: Good goals are ones that you are likely to stick with and achieve some day. Good goals give you something specific to work towards. Some goals, however, are not very useful for making real changes. For example, what’s NOT helpful about setting a goal of “staying out of trouble”? This is a perfectly fine place to start, but the way this goal is stated gives no information about how to achieve it, how long it will take to achieve it, or when you know you’ve reached it. Good goals are also something that you really want and are willing to work for. Have you ever set a goal because someone else wanted you to? How did that turn out for you? It’s not surprising if things didn’t go well. You will succeed at changing only if you want to change. This is not to say that others cannot help or support you with your goals, but they should not create them for you. Review the diagram below.

questions.prompt: Here are some examples - select the BETTER goal:

answers.answer: I will be a great father and husband
will purchase a nice home for my family in 2 years
I will save money each month to build up my savings
I will get rid of my feelings of anxiety
I will take my anxiety medication as prescribed
I will lose 20 pounds within 6 months
I will never catch a technical violation
I will spend 1 hour each day reviewing my relapse prevention plan

pages.text: Do not have goals that include the words “never” or “always.” These are dead man’s goals – only a dead guy could accomplish them! You’re human; don’t set impossible expectations. Cut yourself some slack.

If you set a time frame (2 weeks, 6 months, 5 years) for achieving your goal, check to see if the goal is met when you get to that time frame. If it is – great! If it isn’t – don’t worry. You are not a failure. All you have to do is ask yourself why you didn’t reach the goal. Maybe the time frame was too short. Or, maybe you needed to work harder or do something a little differently.

pages.subheader: Knowing What You Need to Reach Those Goals
pages.text: Writing down your goals is just the start. Now you have to begin planning for the goal. This may even require making smaller goals to achieve a larger goal. You also have to figure out what you need and who can help you. Let’s look at a quick example.

Blake just got out of jail a few weeks ago and he doesn’t have a lot of money. He was sentenced to jail for gambling illegally and selling dope. This was how he earned a living. But, these habits were also part of Blake’s problems that landed him in jail. Blake wants to stay out of trouble, so his goal is to find a full-time job within the next 3 months. This is also a requirement of his supervision. He can’t just walk in anywhere and get hired. He needs help and resources. He takes the bus to the public library and looks through the local newspaper for job ads, uses the computer to make a résumé, and searches the Internet for job openings in his town. Blake also joins a support group for other job seekers and signs up at the employment agency. He asks his brother to help him practice interviewing for jobs – making eye contact, shaking hands, and answering questions. Blake uses money from his savings to buy some nice clothes, so he can make a good impression at his interviews. He soon gets an interview for a job as a maintenance worker at an apartment complex. Blake’s friend, Jake, lives in the same complex. So, he asks Jake to tell him more about the complex – what the residents like and dislike about living there. This information helps Blake play up his strengths (what he can add to the job). Before his interview, he also writes down questions he wants to ask so he’ll be better prepared. Blake doesn’t have a car yet, so he takes the bus.

fields.text: What steps did Blake take to find a job?
What resources or things did he need to help him?
Who did he need to help him?

pages.text: Because of your illegal actions, you are being placed under community supervision to monitor your behavior and help you get back on track. Your placement is meant to be both a punishment or consequence for how you chose to behave in the community and a way for you to make needed changes like get off drugs or find a job. According to the Bureau of Justice Statistics—a government agency that collects data on people in the criminal justice system–about 4.6 million people are being supervised by community corrections departments like the one you report to. If you aren’t new to supervision, some of the information in this section will be a no-brainer (duh!). But, some of the information here is helpful whether you’re a rookie or have been around the block a few times.

People are placed on supervision for various reasons; some are sentenced to probation instead of serving jail time. Others may be on parole because they were released early from prison. The terms of your supervision period may depend on the reason for your placement. The rules also vary from state to state or even from person to person.

Community supervision requirements are stringent and typically include the following: Pay supervision fees—yes, it costs money to be supervised. Try to pay these fees on time so you don’t get behind on what you owe or get charged with late fees. Avoid illegal conduct—it seems pretty obvious that you shouldn’t commit crimes while you’re being punished for one. Avoid contact with other people on supervision outside the building—don’t hang out with other people who engage in crime or who are in trouble for committing a crime. We will talk more about this in a later module. Report any arrests or police contact to your officer. Find stable employment and housing.

Report for mandatory check-ins with supervision officers. Avoid drug use and submit to random drug screenings. Be available for unscheduled home and work visitations from officers. Comply with mandated treatment programming. Obtain permission to travel outside a designated location or change your residence.
